author: eaoe
content: Why is it said that big block size limits such as that of BSC (60,000,000) is bad for the block chain ?

author: djrtwo
content:
primarily unmanaged state growth making it unrealistic that consumer hardware can run the chain after not too long at high gas limits

There are many R&D efforts to make state sustainable in Etheruem and before those are released into production, we have to find a balance on usability (higher gas limit) and sustainability (ehtereum not crumbling under its own weight)

author: djrtwo
content: Additionally, there are block execution (bandwidth and state read/write) and bandwidth bottlenecks you could hit with high gas limits. The read/write issue especially is compounded by large state sizes depending on the client's data model

content: Disk space and I/O. If you want more background you can search for "ethereum state expiry"

author: eaoe
content: I just did some research about Ethereum state  and i have one question i'm having a hard time finding an answer for online, a state is all the smart contracts of the blockchain loaded and ready for execution, or all the smart contracts of the blockchain loaded and ready for execution + everyone's balances ?

author: jacobkaufmann
content: The "world state" is the set of all accounts. Those include non-contract accounts (EOAs) and contract accounts. For EOAs the only state is balance and nonce.  Contract accounts have contract storage and code in addition to balance and nonce
